Knowledge Point: In Tuatschin, \isi{reduplication} has only an intensification function. Syntactic categories that may be reduplicated are attributive (\ref{ex:redadjattr1}) and predicative (\ref{ex:redadjpred1} and \ref{ex:redadjpred2}) adjectives, adjectives used adverbially (\ref{ex:redadjpred3}), as adverbs modifying adjectives (\ref{ex:redadv1}), as adverbs modifying verbs (\ref{ex:redadv2} and \ref{ex:redadv3}), or functioning as a discourse marker (\ref{ex:redadv4}).
Content 1: \gll Ála \textbf{véglja-véglja} tgèsa-parvènda, né? | \gls in.DEF.F.SG RED\textasciitilde{old} presbytery right | \glt `At the very old presbytery, right?'
Content 3: \gll A quaj stèvnṣ èssar … \textbf{pulits-pulits} l’ jamna … tg’ al bap dètschi in frang a miaz. | \gls and DEM.UNM must.IMPF.1PL.1PL COP.INF … RED\textasciitilde{well_behaved}.M.PL DEF.F.SG week … SUBORD DEF.M.SG father give.PRS.SBJV.3SG one.M.SG franc and half.M.SG | \glt `And we had to be … very well-behaved during the week … so that my father would give [us] one and a half francs.'
Content 4: \gll Al tat èr’ ajn a durméva lò grat sc’ in tajṣ, vèv’ udju \textbf{ṣchùbar-ṣchùbar} nuét. | \gls DEF.M.SG grandfather COP.IMPF.3SG up and sleep.IMPF.3SG there precisely like INDEF.M.SG badger have.IMPF.3SG hear.PTCP.UNM RED\textasciitilde{clean}.ADJ.UNM nothing | \glt `My grandfather was up there and was sleeping like a log, he hadn’t heard anything at all.'
Content 5: \gll Ju a gju \textbf{fétg-fétg} bian cun èl. | \gls 1SG have.PRS.1SG have.PTCP.UNM RED\textasciitilde{very} good.UNM with 3SG.M | \glt `I got along very well with him.'
Content 7: \gll A sjantar surpríu acòrds \textbf{adin-adina}. | \gls and after take_over.PTCP.UNM piecework.M.PL RED\textasciitilde{always} | \glt `And afterwards [I] took over piecework, always.'
Content 8: \gll Quaj èra in’ jèda ... brutal tiar nus, \textbf{bèn-bèn}. | \gls DEM.UNM COP.IMPF.3SG one.F time … terrible.ADJ.UNM among 1PL RED\textasciitilde{really} | \glt `Once it was terrible among us, really.'

Knowledge Point: A similar case is the repetition of words (\ref{ex:rep1} and \ref{ex:rep2}). It differs from the \isi{reduplication} insofar as the repeated items are separated by a short pause; they furthermore do not indicate intensification, but only repetition.
Content 1: \gll [...] a lu stuèv’ ju la sèra adin’ ir' a fá tschajna … a fá … \textbf{manèstra}, \textbf{manèstra}, \textbf{manèstra}, \textbf{manèstra}. | \gls … and then must.IMPF.1SG 1SG DEF.F.SG evening always go.INF SUBORD make.INF dinner.F.SG … SUBORD make.INF … pottage.F.SG pottage.F.SG pottage.F.SG pottage.F.SG | \glt `[...] and then in the evening I always had to go and prepare dinner ... and prepare pottage, pottage, pottage, pottage.'
Content 2: \gll [...] a quèl’ èra da \textbf{trá} … \textbf{trá}, \textbf{trá} … tùt al latg cèntrifugau. | \gls … and DEM.F.SG be.IMPF.3SG to pull.INF … pull.INF pull.INF … all DEF.M.SG milk centrifugate.PTCP.UNM | \glt `[...] and we had to pull ... pull, pull ... the whole centrifuged milk.'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Compounding} is achieved by joining two nouns with the preposition da `of' (\ref{ex:tiartgèsa1}), and also by juxtaposition of two nouns (\ref{ex:clutgebaselgja1}), whereby the second noun modifies the first one as in baun-pégna `oven bench', literally `bench-oven'. Which strategy is used depends on the compound, and in some cases the two strategies may apply to the same nouns with different meanings. This last point is best exemplified by (\ref{ex:tiartgèsa1}).
Content 1: \gll In \textbf{tiar} \textbf{da} \textbf{tgèsa}, è `l gjat a `l tgaun, a \textbf{tiar-tgèsa} è sagir tùt quaj tga vò bigj’ ad alp. Als \textbf{tiars-tgèsa} èn atgnamajn cò, né sén majṣès, quaj è quèlas tgauras a nùrsas a pòrs. | \gls INDEF.M.SG animal of house.F.SG COP.PRS.3SG DEF.M.SG cat and DEF.M.SG dog and animal.M.SG-house.F.SG COP.PRS.3SG for_sure all DEM.UNM REL go.PRS.3SG NEG to alpine_pasture.M.SG DEF.M.PL animal.PL-house.F.SG COP.PRS.3PL actually here or on assembly_of_houses.M.SG DEM.GL COP.PRS.3SG DEM.F.PL goat.PL and sheep.F-PL and pig.M.PL | \glt `A tiar da tgèsa, these are cats and dogs, and tiar tgèsa are of course all those that do not go to the alpine pastures. The tiars tgèsa are actually here, or up in the assembly of houses, these are the goats, the sheep, and the pigs.'
Content 3: \gll In \textbf{tiar} \textbf{da} \textbf{tgèsa}, è `l gjat a `l tgaun, a \textbf{tiar-tgèsa} è sagir tùt quaj tga vò bigj’ ad alp. Als \textbf{tiars-tgèsa} èn atgnamajn cò, né sén majṣès, quaj è quèlas tgauras a nùrsas a pòrs. | \gls INDEF.M.SG animal of house.F.SG COP.PRS.3SG DEF.M.SG cat and DEF.M.SG dog and animal.M.SG-house.F.SG COP.PRS.3SG for_sure all DEM.UNM REL go.PRS.3SG NEG to alpine_pasture.M.SG DEF.M.PL animal.PL-house.F.SG COP.PRS.3PL actually here or on assembly_of_houses.M.SG DEM.GL COP.PRS.3SG DEM.F.PL goat.PL and sheep.F-PL and pig.M.PL | \glt `A tiar da tgèsa, these are cats and dogs, and tiar tgèsa are of course all those that do not go to the alpine pastures. The tiars tgèsa are actually here, or up in the assembly of houses, these are the goats, the sheep, and the pigs.'

Knowledge Point: The \isi{diminutive} of nouns is formed with the suffix -èt/-èta. (\ref{ex:dim1}) shows that the use of the \isi{diminutive} does not preclude the use of pin `small'.
Content 1: \gll Lò fùva in pin \textbf{laj-èt} cun pauc’ aua. | \gls there EXIST.IMPF.3SG INDEF.M.SG small lake-DIM with little.F.SG water | \glt `There was a small lake with little water.'

Knowledge Point: There are two \isi{augmentative} suffixes. One is -ún/-una (\ref{ex:aum1} and \ref{ex:aum2}).
Content 1: \gll Quaj è \textbf{dòn-ún}. | \gls DEM.UNM COP.PRS.3SG pity.M.SG-AUGM | \glt `This is a real pity.'
Content 2: \gll Sònda-dumèngja vagnévan quèls ò cò a fagjévan \textbf{fjast-unas}. | \gls Saturday-Sunday come.IMPF.3PL DEM.M.PL out here and do.IMPF.3PL party-AUGM.F.PL | \glt `On week-ends they would come here and have big parties.'

Knowledge Point: The other \isi{augmentative} is -az, as in fòmaz (> fòm `hunger') (\ref{ex:aum3}).
Content 1: \gll Ju a \textbf{fòm-az}. | \gls 1SG have.PRS.1SG hunger-AUGM | \glt `I am ravenous.'
